The Art of Bushmiller
Everyone knows its hard to find a
solid investment these days, but classic
comic strips seem to be a promising
prospect.
This week, Sotheby-Park
Bernet will be auctioning three original
daily installments of Ernie Bushmiller's
great Nancy strip. Experts value each
four-panel at no less than $500 and
expect them to go for more. All agree
that these are the finest examples of
Bushmiller's controversial Marxist period

of the late Forties, during which he was
adapting his expressionistic drawing technique to an increasingly leftist perspective. A limited series of lithographs of
the Sunday color Nancy strips of Bushmiller's Fauvist period are being offered
by Dinty Moore Limited Editions, a
Baltimore art publishing firm, for $350 a
piece. If a price tag like that doesn't label
it as A rt , then what the hell does?

Life-Style

Inexpensive Health
and Beauty Aids
The cost of living is skyrocketing,
but you still want to look your best
So here are some inexpensive health and
beauty aids you can create with common
household products.

deodorant is
too expensive
A very fine, subtly scented shampoo
can be made with dishwashing detergent.
Combine one cup lemon-scented detergent, one egg, and a pinch of cinnamon.
Buzz in the blender and it's ready to use.
To add body, rinse with the beer of your

choice.
Face it, deodorant is too expensive
and doesn't make you smell like a rose
anyway. Why not just give up buying the
stuff? Somewhere under your kitchen
sink is a dusty can of Raid. A quick
spritz under each arm will achieve the
same effect as your old deodorant and
Raid had the added advantage of keeping
the bugs away.
What is aftershave lotion really made
of? Aloohol, of course. Its purpose is to
prevent infection after you've scraped the,
top layer of your epidermis away. Now.
you must have a teeny bit of high-proof
alcohol somewhere in your house...maybe
a little cooking sherry? Well, after your
next shave, slap it on. You'll get over
that initial sting and you'll carry the
aroma of the good times with you for the
rest of the day.
Have you ever found yourself facing

an important day, but alas, there was no
mouthwash in the medicine cabinet?
Don't despair, a quick gargle with cheap
vodka will do the trick. It "kills germs on
contact" and, what is more, vodka does it

A very fine, subtly scented
shampoo can be made with
dishwashing detergent
all without a "mediciney taste." A whole
quart of the stuff will probably last
you a lifetime and costs only about $5,if
you shop around for the bargains.

Form Follows Function
As times change,so do the uses of
our living space. And as styles change,so
does that which one's living space is
supposed to express.
We all remember how Le Corbusier's maxim "Form follows Function"
revolutionized interior decorating. Now,
in some circles there is a return to the
"High tech" mechanization of the Le
Corbusien doctrine.
And what man can forget the
onslaught of the sterile, clean environment. We were told that it was best to
express the more "feminine" side of our
personalities, that neat and clean were
symbols of our newly found sensitivity.
But today, the "Me Decade" has
finally caught up with interior decorating.
And at the same time, one interpretation
of "Form follows function" is incorporated into our new decorating scheme.

If you're
comfortable
leaving your bed
unmade,don't
make it
A college man's apartment serves
two purposes: first it is a place to live,"to
live" incorporates eating, sleeping, entertaining, and all that we do for ourselves,
the other purpose is a place to study.
Thus it is no longer necessary to
keep things which impede your studying
or living. But most importantly,and here
enters the "me" aspect, you should no
longer feel tied to conventions of what
constitutes a "home." If you're comfortable leaving your bed unmade, don't
make it. A made bed impeds the true
function. Why make a bed just to unmake it? It's much easier to leave it as is
in the morning and pick up where you
left off that night.

The same is true of things. Dishes
will only procede to get dirty. Books put
on shelves will have to be taken off again.
All this menial housework stands opposed
to the functions of your apartment,living
and studying.
Some friends ask me if this type
of apartment living isn't worrisome when
entertaining. I don't think so. Be yourself and let people see the real you, not
the "well-mannered" or "trained" you
that makes us all so similar, but the you
beneath all of that. If you drink a lot of
beer, let people know it. Don't feel you
have to hide the empty bottles. If
you had spaghetti last night, don't be
ashamed, plenty of people eat spaghetti let the dishes rest! If you smoke a lot,let
the ashtrays overflow; besides, you never
know when you'll run out.
You see, there's nothing wrong
with being yourself and letting people see
how you're most comfortable. The
function is your comfort, and the style is
you.
"But," you may ask, "what if I
The apartment came
can't be me?
furnished and doesn't express me." This
problem arises frequently for the college
man. The answer is simple. The new style
is not to set guidelines or to consult rule
books; you don't have to put the typewriter on the typing table. You can do
whatever you want. Just as you consider
the layout of the apartment a "given," so
too is the furniture that comes with it. If
you don't like it, bury it. For this you
can use your clothes or some old newspaper.
"But I share a place with someone. What if ME and HIM clash." The
only thing I find more invigorating than a
Bach fugue is the counterpoint of two
different ME styles expressed simultaneously. If your roommate can't stand
the way you leave your things lying
around, leave his things lying around
instead. The dichotomy of separate ME
styles is particularly interesting when
entertaining. Newcomers to your place
will expose their true opinions of you. If
they think the wine glasses are yours and
the National Boh cans your roommates',
then let them think you have more class
than him. This can be particularly

Foot odor? No problem. Just dust
your shoes once a week with Comet.
This trick works even better than "odor.
eaters."

Then our Christmas installment will
look at whether it is safe to leave your
Christmas tree up until Easter.
--Ray D. Aider

now another, more haunting
thought hit him: had he completely
ruined his chances for a brilliant
career in private practice?
Guilt plagued him throughout the day. By dinnertime he
could stand it no longer and he
burst out of the D-Level carrels in a
sweat, mumbling incoherently.
It's not worth it, he told
himself in the elevator up to the
main floor of the library. Love
simply must take a back seat to
study, there was no getting around
it. He would have to tell Carotene
right away, before she started
getting serious. Sure, she would
be hurt, but it would be better for
her in the long run. No, Wendell
Fortinbras could not let a woman,
not even Carotene Bettelheim,
stand in the way of his goal.
The doors slid open and he
almost bumped into Carotene on
her way in. He turned and called
to her but she gave no notice.

ing floors until he found her among

Mary: Ah Girls! I will always remember
John for the voluptuous sport he afforded me, shall I say the free play of the
faculties. Was it but less fleeting! But
alas, Love, like Youth, flies with the
wings of Time's shifting sands, and
L'ennui is a snake in the lush grasses of
Desire. John was a man of contemplation
when first we met,his fair eyes transfixed
as if on some point far in the blue distance. Fairly a Hamlet he was,and I, his
butterfly, Ophelia. I imagined he must be
a poet, but actually he was a man- of
science. (Though the way he scratched
his limbs, I feared lest he had accruedthe
dropsy.) Of what thoughts he populated
the void of his mind's cavity, I knew not,
neither did I care; I would fain speculate
on the perfect volcano of smothered
desire that surely bubbled and spewed

forth the hot lava of d'amour beneath his
cool smooth brow.
I know the moment I set my
dewy eyes on the sleek line of his manly
form in that hive of, Love's pilgrims, the
Rathskellar, that, indeed,he would desire
a peek at my charming calf, and perhaps,
I hoped, at the divinity of my burnished
marblelike thigh.
I approached, my
nerves all aquiver, to ask what o'clock it
might be. With gentlemanly sobriety, he
consulted his dial. Ah, the smooth
delicacy of those fingers that might
fondle the poles of my panting white
globes. Did he, in his flower of innocence, suspect my bold passion? No,
he was far too absorbed in the furnishings
of his mind's chamber. It was for me to
draw him out as one might the pearly
droplet of honey from it's suckle. With
pervasisve elequence, I drew his liquid
eyes from that inward focus onto the
threshold of my ruby lips and the purling
depths of my fawn like eyes.
We danced and I coultl sense the
sleeping giants of his biceps flexing,with
the ghythm of the simple melody that the
minstrels played. My eyes made their
sweet pilgramage to what I imagined as

the downy concavity of his loins and, ah
but I must quickly execute the thought
lest he think me over brazen a maid, the
seeming knot, the dart of Love,that pert
Mr. Priapus, who made his dwelling in
Love's furrow there. Perhaps merely a
modest blush would betray my rapturous
sentiments with proper poise. The music
had become too loud for the employment
of comely forms of speech in my pursuit
of Love's fulfillment.
And such it was that I induced
this reluctant Odysseus to taste of life's
rich tapestry and his body's hermit to
enter the mossy grotto between my
thighs. Alas how innocent a pupil he
was and what trials I encountered in
training him to properly wield his weapon. Summarily, I would have awarded
him an A for effort, a D for accuracy.
Nevertheless, we were happy for a
time: the pleasure of a stroll between
classes, a warm brew at the coffee
shoppe, those evenings we read aloud- to
one another until the book fell from our
blushing fingertips in a fresh onslaught of
desire. Yet that wiley helmsman of
Love's ship desired to steer our sweet
vessel to boiling waters and rockier shores

where we would encounter our separate
destinies and drink the visceral draught of
loneliness. John said that I had set him
panning for that kernal of'genius at his
soul's depth. He felt called upon to write
poetry, learn to pluck the guitar, and to
search for himself in that exotic land of
many veils, The East. He left me to find
that cocoa-skinned woman who would be
his new guide toward Passion's hidden
treasure. Shall I wait like Penelope for
my sea-weary boy to return a man? Or
does not a brilliant new Apollo rise on
the mind's horizon with every rosy dawn;
John: Mary taught me all I know of
sexual congress, and I love and respect
her for that. Sometimes I think we were
too passionate for this modern age we live
in. We made a chemical reaction with the
power of TNT. When I began tutoring
Ling, a fellow bio major, in her English
grammar it was too much for Mary, and
she never forgave me for what she
imagined was a deep betrayal. I loved
Mary, but sometines I'm glad we went
our separate ways. There are so many
other ewes to tup in the fields of Life.
I'll always remember her with fondness as
the woman who made me the man I am.

JHU I.D. when tooling about campus
after the blackout shades have been
drawn. (Not only does the card alleviate
suspicion in the minds of the local
constabulatory, it is also quite useful for
opening the front doors of dorms when
some ass displays enough common sense
to lock them at night.) Furthermore, had
Mr. Golden himself been the victim of an
attack near the Art Museum (for Theonia's benefit, this is the scurvy area where
bestiality and culture often enjoy an
after-hours rendezvous) I am sure that we
would now be reading his letter telling us
how Campus Security let someone in the
area stroll by while dusting his throat for
fingerprints. Let's give our Felony Squad
boys a break-even; Lt. Tragg had to start
his dogged bloodhound work somewhere.
Of course the real answer for students
rests in the establishment of an effective
escort service, one accessible to all
students regardless of race, creed or bicep
size. Get the message, Major?
I guess that about concludes my
horn-blowing for this semester. Although
it does get a tad lonesome out here in the
land Mary Bass forgot, I feel confident
that this missive has succeeded in pissingoff enough people to keep this column
full for months, and make me all sorts of
new friends.
Happy Holidays!
Ubiquitously yours,
Dixie Dick
Sports-Editor-in-Exile
Maplewood, Missouri

journey to the Rat! That might be
Theonia behind that Sangria pitcher!

The Art of Bushmiller
Everyone knows its hard to find a
solid investment these days, but classic
comic strips seem to be a promising
prospect.
This week, Sotheby-Park
Bernet will be auctioning three original
daily installments of Ernie Bushmiller's
great Nancy strip. Experts value each
four-panel at no less than $500 and
expect them to go for more. All agree
that these are the finest examples of
Bushmiller's controversial Marxist period

of the late Forties, during which he was
adapting his expressionistic drawing technique to an increasingly leftist perspective. A limited series of lithographs of
the Sunday color Nancy strips of Bushmiller's Fauvist period are being offered
by Dinty Moore Limited Editions, a
Baltimore art publishing firm, for $350 a
piece. If a price tag like that doesn't label
it as A rt , then what the hell does?

The cost of living is skyrocketing,
but you still want to look your best
So here are some inexpensive health and
beauty aids you can create with common
household products.

deodorant is
too expensive
A very fine, subtly scented shampoo
can be made with dishwashing detergent.
Combine one cup lemon-scented detergent, one egg, and a pinch of cinnamon.
Buzz in the blender and it's ready to use.
To add body, rinse with the beer of your

choice.
Face it, deodorant is too expensive
and doesn't make you smell like a rose
anyway. Why not just give up buying the
stuff? Somewhere under your kitchen
sink is a dusty can of Raid. A quick
spritz under each arm will achieve the
same effect as your old deodorant and
Raid had the added advantage of keeping
the bugs away.

of? Aloohol, of course. Its purpose is to
prevent infection after you've scraped the,
top layer of your epidermis away. Now.
you must have a teeny bit of high-proof
alcohol somewhere in your house...maybe
a little cooking sherry? Well, after your
next shave, slap it on. You'll get over
that initial sting and you'll carry the
aroma of the good times with you for the
rest of the day.

Form Follows Function
As times change,so do the uses of
our living space. And as styles change,so
does that which one's living space is
supposed to express.
We all remember how Le Corbusier's maxim "Form follows Function"
revolutionized interior decorating. Now,
in some circles there is a return to the
"High tech" mechanization of the Le
Corbusien doctrine.
And what man can forget the
onslaught of the sterile, clean environment. We were told that it was best to
express the more "feminine" side of our
personalities, that neat and clean were
symbols of our newly found sensitivity.
But today, the "Me Decade" has
finally caught up with interior decorating.
And at the same time, one interpretation
of "Form follows function" is incorporated into our new decorating scheme.

If you're
comfortable
leaving your bed
unmade,don't
make it
A college man's apartment serves
two purposes: first it is a place to live,"to
live" incorporates eating, sleeping, entertaining, and all that we do for ourselves,
the other purpose is a place to study.
Thus it is no longer necessary to
keep things which impede your studying
or living. But most importantly,and here
enters the "me" aspect, you should no
longer feel tied to conventions of what
constitutes a "home." If you're comfortable leaving your bed unmade, don't
make it. A made bed impeds the true
function. Why make a bed just to unmake it? It's much easier to leave it as is
in the morning and pick up where you
left off that night.

The same is true of things. Dishes
will only procede to get dirty. Books put
on shelves will have to be taken off again.
All this menial housework stands opposed
to the functions of your apartment,living
and studying.
Some friends ask me if this type
of apartment living isn't worrisome when
entertaining. I don't think so. Be yourself and let people see the real you, not
the "well-mannered" or "trained" you
that makes us all so similar, but the you
beneath all of that. If you drink a lot of
beer, let people know it. Don't feel you
have to hide the empty bottles. If
you had spaghetti last night, don't be
ashamed, plenty of people eat spaghetti let the dishes rest! If you smoke a lot,let
the ashtrays overflow; besides, you never
know when you'll run out.
You see, there's nothing wrong
with being yourself and letting people see
how you're most comfortable. The
function is your comfort, and the style is
you.
"But," you may ask, "what if I
The apartment came
can't be me?
furnished and doesn't express me." This
problem arises frequently for the college
man. The answer is simple. The new style
is not to set guidelines or to consult rule
books; you don't have to put the typewriter on the typing table. You can do
whatever you want. Just as you consider
the layout of the apartment a "given," so
too is the furniture that comes with it. If
you don't like it, bury it. For this you
can use your clothes or some old newspaper.
"But I share a place with someone. What if ME and HIM clash." The
only thing I find more invigorating than a
Bach fugue is the counterpoint of two
different ME styles expressed simultaneously. If your roommate can't stand
the way you leave your things lying
around, leave his things lying around
instead. The dichotomy of separate ME
styles is particularly interesting when
entertaining. Newcomers to your place
will expose their true opinions of you. If
they think the wine glasses are yours and
the National Boh cans your roommates',
then let them think you have more class
than him. This can be particularly

Mary: Ah Girls! I will always remember
John for the voluptuous sport he afforded me, shall I say the free play of the
faculties. Was it but less fleeting! But
alas, Love, like Youth, flies with the
wings of Time's shifting sands, and
L'ennui is a snake in the lush grasses of
Desire. John was a man of contemplation
when first we met,his fair eyes transfixed
as if on some point far in the blue distance. Fairly a Hamlet he was,and I, his
butterfly, Ophelia. I imagined he must be
a poet, but actually he was a man- of
science. (Though the way he scratched
his limbs, I feared lest he had accruedthe
dropsy.) Of what thoughts he populated
the void of his mind's cavity, I knew not,
neither did I care; I would fain speculate
on the perfect volcano of smothered
desire that surely bubbled and spewed

forth the hot lava of d'amour beneath his
cool smooth brow.
I know the moment I set my
dewy eyes on the sleek line of his manly
form in that hive of, Love's pilgrims, the
Rathskellar, that, indeed,he would desire
a peek at my charming calf, and perhaps,
I hoped, at the divinity of my burnished
marblelike thigh.
I approached, my
nerves all aquiver, to ask what o'clock it
might be. With gentlemanly sobriety, he
consulted his dial. Ah, the smooth
delicacy of those fingers that might
fondle the poles of my panting white
globes. Did he, in his flower of innocence, suspect my bold passion? No,
he was far too absorbed in the furnishings
of his mind's chamber. It was for me to
draw him out as one might the pearly
droplet of honey from it's suckle. With
pervasisve elequence, I drew his liquid
eyes from that inward focus onto the
threshold of my ruby lips and the purling
depths of my fawn like eyes.
We danced and I coultl sense the
sleeping giants of his biceps flexing,with
the ghythm of the simple melody that the
minstrels played. My eyes made their
sweet pilgramage to what I imagined as

the downy concavity of his loins and, ah
but I must quickly execute the thought
lest he think me over brazen a maid, the
seeming knot, the dart of Love,that pert
Mr. Priapus, who made his dwelling in
Love's furrow there. Perhaps merely a
modest blush would betray my rapturous
sentiments with proper poise. The music
had become too loud for the employment
of comely forms of speech in my pursuit
of Love's fulfillment.
And such it was that I induced
this reluctant Odysseus to taste of life's
rich tapestry and his body's hermit to
enter the mossy grotto between my
thighs. Alas how innocent a pupil he
was and what trials I encountered in

Nevertheless, we were happy for a

one another until the book fell from our
blushing fingertips in a fresh onslaught of
desire. Yet that wiley helmsman of

vessel to boiling waters and rockier shores

his new guide toward Passion's hidden
treasure. Shall I wait like Penelope for
my sea-weary boy to return a man? Or
does not a brilliant new Apollo rise on
the mind's horizon with every rosy dawn;
John: Mary taught me all I know of

imagined was a deep betrayal. I loved
Mary, but sometines I'm glad we went

opening the front doors of dorms when
some ass displays enough common sense
to lock them at night.) Furthermore, had
Mr. Golden himself been the victim of an
attack near the Art Museum (for Theonia's benefit, this is the scurvy area where
bestiality and culture often enjoy an
after-hours rendezvous) I am sure that we
would now be reading his letter telling us
how Campus Security let someone in the
area stroll by while dusting his throat for
fingerprints. Let's give our Felony Squad
boys a break-even; Lt. Tragg had to start
his dogged bloodhound work somewhere.
Of course the real answer for students
rests in the establishment of an effective
escort service, one accessible to all
students regardless of race, creed or bicep
size. Get the message, Major?
I guess that about concludes my
horn-blowing for this semester. Although
it does get a tad lonesome out here in the
land Mary Bass forgot, I feel confident
that this missive has succeeded in pissingoff enough people to keep this column
full for months, and make me all sorts of
new friends.
Happy Holidays!
Ubiquitously yours,
Dixie Dick
Sports-Editor-in-Exile
Maplewood, Missouri

journey to the Rat! That might be
Theonia behind that Sangria pitcher!
